quoteLast: We find the sun very hot and scorching, but all try to keep out of it as much as we can.

quoteLast: and everybody was sorry to see us go. Those scouts, and the Uncle Tom’s Cabin people, and a lot of old veterans, all crowded around us to say good-by.

quoteFirst: The smoke of the guns seen from the top of the Residency! Oh joy! they say they are only four or five miles off! but they have to fight their way in! quoteFirst: "The whole affair was conducted with the utmost decency and decorum; there was the greatest gaiety, cheerfulness and complacency in every countenance. The ball was concluded
quoteLast: and the night was passed in the general satisfaction, without the least incivility offered or offence taken by any one, which is scarce to be said on the like occasions. We are told this was distinguished by the title of the Country Ball.
title: Old Taverns of New York

quoteFirst: Lieutenant Macdowell, second in command of Hodson's Horse--an eye-witness--says: "The steadiness with which the cavalry confronted this most anxious position for two hours is as deserving of praise as the courage of the infantry who carried the breaches.  At three a.m. we moved down in column of squadrons to the rear of our batteries, and waited there till
quoteLast: , when the enemy advanced from the Lahore gate with two troops of artillery, no end of cavalry, and a lot of infantry, apparently to our front.  I think that they intended to try and take their old position now that we had got theirs.
title: Our Soldiers: Gallant Deeds of the British Army during Victoria's Reign
author: Kingston, William Henry Giles, 1814-1880

quoteFirst: “Next morning, the 5th of March (a day to be remembered in the annals of the Thirteenth Hussars), we moved off
quoteLast: and proceeded up the Tigris, in the teeth of a terrible sand-storm, which blinded both horses and men, and through which we could only see 80 to 100 yards ahead of us. Suddenly, out to our front, we heard the sound of rifle-fire, and bullets whizzed amongst us.
title: The Thirteenth Hussars in the Great War
author: Durand, H. Mortimer (Henry Mortimer), 1850-1924

quoteFirst: The morning "newspapers" were transmitted to the sleeping subscribers by wire at
quoteLast: The great newspaper offices had hundreds of Hypnobioscopes in operation, the subscriber's wire leading to them. The newspaper office, notified by each subscriber what kind of news is desirable, furnished only such news.
title: Ralph 124C 41+: A Romance of the Year 2660

quoteFirst: The day of the Spank had a bad openin'. When Deedee woke up, along
quoteLast: , it was rainin' pitchforks, and that meant a day indoors, and to start off, she stood up in her crib and called for “laim.”

quoteFirst: Lightened by the flames she floated off the bar and drifted, a huge pyramid of fire, down the river illuminating its broad expanse till all was bright as day, and revealing the shattered vessels of the fleet as they hastily steamed out of the way of their dangerous consort. Long after she had passed around the bend the light of the flames reflected on the sky marked her progress.
quoteLast: , when at almost the identical spot where the Confederate ram “Arkansas” was blown up, the fire reached the magazine and the “Mississippi” existed only in story. The shock of the explosion was felt at Port Hudson, twenty miles distant.
title: Company K, First Alabama Regiment; or, Three Years in the Confederate Service
author: Smith, Daniel P.

quoteFirst: It was a beautiful moonlight night and I stood and watched the bombs from the mortar boats curling around in the sky and bursting in a fiery show, making a splendid sight. The night passed quietly, save for a couple of false alarms. At
quoteLast: , Jared Wells, my old tent mate, and I went out blackberrying. In a little while we had enough for a good meal for ourselves and some for the boys in camp.

quoteFirst: It was freezing hard, and I fear the poor fellows wished me and my luggage no good when, after much striving, we were finally afloat, and they resumed their places at the oars. In the dark the great hull loomed gigantic as,
quoteLast: , we pulled alongside of the steamer, which turned out to be the _Iberia_, one of the largest and finest vessels of the Pacific Company, commanded by Captain Shannon.
title: Notes of a naturalist in South America
author: Ball, John, 1818-1889

quoteFirst: Congratulations over, chairs are cleared away, rugs taken up and the room made ready for dancing till supper, Leschetizky playing for at least part of the evening. Toasts, speeches, stories, and laughter fill the hours till early morning, when,
quoteLast: , a happy, but exhausted, procession streams homeward, stopping on the way at some café--if it is not yet 6 o'clock--to make sure the hall-porter, with his dripping candle and everlasting demand for his ten-kreutzer fee, will be safely gone to his lair.
title: Theodor Leschetizky
author: Hullah, Annette

quoteFirst: There was no wind now, but there had been

quoteFirst: Taking leave of my friends on board, I landed at
quoteLast: , and, having committed my luggage, a small bullock trunk, saddle-bags, and a saddle, to the shoulders of a sturdy facchino, and myself to a very rickety and diminutive cart, I proceeded on my way to Ragusa. The drive, about a mile and a half in distance, abounds with pretty views, while the town of Ragusa itself is as picturesque in its interior detail as it is interesting from its early history.

quoteLast: It was a very imposing sight. It moved first as one solid block, carrying boats, stacks of timber, sledge roads--everything--with it.
